description: Attested since 1430. From Middle English incredulite, from Old French incredulité, from Late Latin incredulitas, from Latin incredulus (“unbelieving”) + -itas (“-ity”), equivalent to incredulous +‎ -ity.

entries.meaning: Unwillingness or inability to believe; doubt about the truth or verisimilitude of something; disbelief.
examples: Wide went her eyes in wonder and incredulity, as she beheld this seeming apparition risen from the dead.
